School of Chemical Engineering Anhui University of Science and Technology Huainan 232001 PR China Dry reforming of methane (DRM) over Ni-based catalysts is a vital strategy of significant economic and environmental benefits to mitigate the greenhouse effect and facilitate syngas generation, in which catalyst deactivation is the critical bottleneck due to metal sinter and carbon deposition. Herein, a series of NixPt(1-x)Co@0.25C-A (x = 0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1) catalysts were synthesized and employed in DRM. Results demonstrated that regulating Pt/Co content could induce the formation of Ni-Pt-Co trimetallic alloy interfaces and affect the CH/CO bond cracking ability of as-synthesized catalysts. Ce addition in zeolite pre-crystallization process was favorable to increase the oxygen vacancy (VO) concentration to promote CO2 dissociation and coke removal. In addition, Ce species could strongly interact with the trimetallic alloy sites and skeleton silicon by electron transfer, and thus achieving the strong anchoring effect of clay-based zeolite support on active sites and restricting its sinter and phase segregation. Consequently, Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A catalyst, which equips with the superior Ce-interacted Ni-Pt-Co trimetallic alloy interfaces and high VO concentration as well as abundant surface medium-strength alkaline sites, exhibited the highest CH4/CO2 initial conversion of 80 %/71 % and had 7 % of activity loss after 100 h of long-term stability tests. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Dry reforming of methane Syngas Ni-based clay catalysts Trimetallic alloy interfaces Ce addition Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction Methane (CH4) and carbon dioxide (CO2), generally regarded as the two most significant contributors to anthropogenic climate rise, can be translated into syngas (composed of CO and H2) by dry reforming of methane (DRM) above 700 ℃, to further manufacture value-added chemicals and liquid fuels by the processes such as hydroformylation, carbonylation, Fischer-Tropsch, and so on [1,2]. Due to the high reforming efficiency, abundant reserves and good economic suitability, Ni-based catalysts are identified as the brightest candidate for DRM [3]. Nevertheless, it is absent in commercial DRM process hitherto, attributing to metal sintering and carbon deposition caused in-situ catalyst activity loss [4]. One promising strategy to achieve persistent high catalytic activity of Ni-based catalysts is to rationally construct Ni-M alloys using other transition metals of analogical crystal texture (Fe, Co, Cu or Zn) [5–8]. The bimetallic synergistic effect not only preserves the original catalytic features of metals, but also can regulate its electronic structure to improve DRM performance. Ni-Co alloys have been investigated for a long time in CH4-CO2 reforming for syngas production. Generally, CH4 activation over Ni clusters were completed mainly via a process that Ni atoms inserted into CH bonds transferred abundant self-electron density into the antibonding orbitals of CH bonds. By means of dynamics and density functional theory (DFT) calculations, Tu et al. [6] explored the CH bond activation pathways over Ni and Ni-Co clusters, and found that Co atom in Ni-Co clusters could interact with vicinal adsorbed oxygen adatoms to form Co-oxygen site-pairs, and then CH could be cracked more effectively by a σ bond metathesis reaction, due to the high oxygen affinity of Co metal. Furthermore, the involving oxygen adatoms were beneficial for in-situ carbon deposition removal. The group of Jiang and Ge [9] demonstrated that the existence of Ni-Co alloys in Ni0.8Co0.2/H-ZrO2 catalyst could maintain the balance between CH4 cracking speed and CO2 reduction speed, achieving 75 % of CH4 conversion and 80 % of CO2 conversion. Basing on the promotion effect of Ni on CH4 cracking and that of Co on Boudouard reaction, Horlyck et al. [10] found that Ni-Co alloys could improve catalytic activity and selectivity by regulating the two reactions. However, the attempt utilizing monometallic Co to decorate the interaction between Ni metal sites and reactants/intermediates to restrict the formation of carbon deposits, remain limited. Additionally, the result of our previous work [11] on developing attapulgite-derived MFI zeolite encapsulated Ni-Co alloys in DRM reaction also proves this viewpoint. Numerous studies [12–15] have revealed that combining transition metals with a small amount noble metals can efficaciously modify catalyst electronic and geometric characters to satisfy the requirement for DRM reaction network. Pt metal was reported having an appropriate surface segregation energy on Ni, which ensured the formed Ni-Pt alloys with higher stability. For instance, Niu et al. [16] adopted a systematical DFT to compare the DRM performance over Ni@Pt (111) with that over Ni (111) and Pt (111) surfaces, and found that the existed Pt (111) in Ni@Pt (111) induced a OH*-assisted CH4 dehydrogenation mechanism, which could lower the energy demand for CH and C oxidation to accelerate carbon elimination and enhance anti-carbon capability. What's more, Pt presents superior tuning ability in Co-based catalysts. The H2-spillover effect of Pt can adjust the reducibility of Co to form Co-Pt alloys rich in surface adsorbed oxygen species, to increase catalytic performance [17]. In the investigations of Chen et al. [18] concentrated on developing Co-Pt/MgO-Al2O3 bimetallic catalysts, 0.02 of Pt/Co weight ratio had the strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) that inhibited the agglomeration of alloy nanoparticles and the formation of inactive filamentous or graphitic carbon during DRM process. Nonetheless, to the best of our knowledge, the impact of Pt on regulating Ni-Co alloy interface and the role of Ni-Pt-Co trimetallic synergism mechanism in DRM reaction has not been clearly illustrated yet. Attapulgite-derived MFI (ADM) zeolite, which has demonstrated good thermal stability, typical micropore-mesopore composited channels and high surface area in the previous works [11,19], is a DRM catalyst support of important potential. The lattice oxygen (OL) mobility and adsorbed oxygen (OAds) concentration of support have great significance in carbon deposition elimination [20–22], and the generation of OAds species is generally closely linked with oxygen vacancy (VO). As one of VO-containing metal oxides, CeO2 was widely adopted to build zeolite defect sites and applied in the fields such as volatile organic compounds (VOCs) degradation [23], ammonia selective catalytic reduction [24], and trichloroethylene oxidation [25]. The group of Usui [24] demonstrated that adding moderate Ce cations benefited for stabilizing the SSZ-13 zeolite skeleton. Mahfouz et al. [26] revealed that Ce incorporation could ameliorate DRM stability over Ni-Ru/Ce-KIT-6 catalyst attributing to the increased basicity, reducibility and metal dispersion. Despite there exist many investigations concentrated on exploring the functions of Ce in zeolite skeleton, the effect of CeO2 as a modifier doping into ADM skeleton on catalyst redox property, surface oxygen-containing species activity and synergistic effect with active center are still rarely deeply reported in DRM. Herein, catalysts of Ni-Pt-Co trimetallic supported on Ce-modified ADM were fabricated using a one-pot method. Basing on various advanced characterizations, the impact of adjustable loading amounts of Pt and Co on the electronic structure and microstructure evolutions of trimetallic alloy interfaces was systematically investigated. Additionally, in virtue of in-situ DRIFTS technology, the mechanism of alloy interface formation-transformation, the role of Ce in zeolite skeleton on stabling active centers, and CH4-CO2 reforming procedures were further explored. 2 Experiments 2.1 Catalyst synthesis Materials: Nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O), cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O), cerium(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)2·6H2O), glucose (C6H12O6), platinum tetrammine nitrate (H12N6O6Pt), tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH, 25 wt.%), and sodium hydroxide (NaOH) purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd, were all at analytical grade. Other analytical grade chemicals used in support modification and control group catalyst synthesis such as ethylene glycol and 1,3-propanediamine were also from the same manufacturer. Except for the attapulgite (ATP) clay from Xuyi City in China that should be treated in 3.5 M hydrochloric acid solution at 180 ℃ for 12 h to obtain HATP (the synthesis process has already covered in the previous work [11]), the remainder can be used directly without further purification. To simplify the name of the following catalyst, ADM zeolite was abbreviated as A, and Ce-modified ADM zeolite with different Ce/Si molar ratios was abbreviated as yC-A (y = 0.05, 0.15, 0.25, and 0.35). Synthesis of the NixPt(1-x)Co@0.25C-A catalysts: The NixPt(1-x)Co@0.25C-A catalysts with nominal Ni content of 10 wt.% were synthesized using a one-pot hydrothermal method, among which x and 1-x (x = 0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1) indicated the nominal loading contents of Pt and Co metals, y (y = 0.05, 0.15, 0.25, and 0.35) referred to the Ce/Si molar ratios in as-prepared catalysts. Taking the Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A catalyst as an example, 0.05 g NaOH and 1.45 g HATP were dispersed into 9 mL DI water, and then the mixed solution that was consisted of 5.27 g TPAOH, 2.62 g Ce(NO3)2·6H2O and 9 mL DI water formed by constantly stirring at 35 ℃ for 30 min was added drop-by-drop. After stirring at 35 ℃ for 6 h, Ce-containing gel could be produced. Quantitative metal precursor salts (containing Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, Co(NO3)2·6H2O, and H12N6O6Pt) and glucose were firstly dissolved in 6 mL of water respectively, mixed completely and then slowly added to the gel above mentioned, which were followed with continuous stir for 2 h at 35 ℃ and with hydrothermal treatment for 48 h at 180 ℃ in a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. It is noted that the molar ratios of glucose to metal ions were all a constant 2. The obtained slurry was filtrated, washed, dried at 100 ℃ overnight and then calcined in air for 5 h at 650 ℃ with the heating rate of 4 ℃·min−1. Note, Ni0Pt1Co@0.25C-A and Ni1Pt0Co@0.25C-A were abbreviated as Ni1Co@0.25C-A and Ni1Pt@0.25C-A catalysts, and their synthesis process was in line with that of Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A catalyst except for the absence of H12N6O6Pt and Co(NO3)2·6H2O, respectively. Synthesis of the Ni1Co@yC-A (y = 0.05, 0.15, 0.25, 0.35) and Ni1Co@A catalysts with various complexing agents and hydrothermal time: A series of Ni1Co@yC-A (y = 0.05, 0.15, 0.25, 0.35) and Ni1Co@A catalysts were prepared using the same procedure above mentioned, except for the former changed the amount of Ce(NO3)2·6H2O and did not use H12N6O6Pt, while the latter changed the complexing agents (glucose, ethylene glycol, and 1,3-propanediamine) and hydrothermal time (24, 48, 72, and 96 h) without addition of Ce(NO3)2·6H2O and H12N6O6Pt. Synthesis of the Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@A catalyst: Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@A catalyst was prepared using the same procedure of Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A catalyst synthesis above mentioned, except for the absence of Ce(NO3)2·6H2O. For data accuracy, the actual loading of Ni, Co and Pt in NixPt(1-x)Co@0.25C-A and Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@A catalysts were measured using ICP-OES, and the results are shown in Table S1. 2.2 Catalyst performance evaluation Both the catalytic activity and stability of the as-synthesized DRM catalysts were evaluated in a fixed-bed reactor (YZμBPR-G3-L1-BH, Shanghai Yanzheng Experimental Instrument Co., Ltd., Shanghai, China). 100 mg catalyst was firstly diluted with 400 mg silicon carbide, and then loaded into the reactor middle using two layers of quartz cotton. Prior the DRM tests, the catalyst should be reduced in 100 mL·min−1 10 vol.% H2/N2 continuous stream for 2 h at 700 ℃ to form surface metal sites, and then pure N2 flow was injected for 15 min to remove residual reducing gas. Then, the feed was switched into reactants (CH4/CO2/N2 = 1/1/3) at a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 60,000 mL⋅gcat −1⋅h−1. The exit gas collected every 30 min in a sealed aluminum foil bag was injected into an offline gas chromatographic apparatus equipped with a TCD detector and a TDX-01 column, to analyze and obtain the molar flow rates of each compositions in the exit gas basing on external standard method. The final CH4/CO2 conversions, H2/CO molar ratio were calculated using the following equations: (1) XCH4 CH4 conversion = (FCH4, in- FCH4, out) / FCH4, in × 100 % (2) XCO2 CO2 conversion = (FCO2, in- FCO2, out) / FCO2, in × 100 % (3) H2/CO molar ratio = FH2, out / FCO, out note, where FCH4, in (FCO2, in) and FCH4, out (FCO2, out) indicated the molar flow rates of CH4 (CO2) in inlet or exit gasses, FH2, out and FCO, out represented the molar flow rates of produced H2 and CO. 2.3 Catalyst characterizations The used instrument types and test conditions of catalyst characterizations are exhibited in the supplementary information in detail. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Design strategy of NixPt(1-x)co@0.25C-A catalysts The synthesis procedure for NixPt(1-x)Co@0.25C-A catalysts is summarized in Fig. 1(a) . Basing on the previous work [11], the method was further modified by changing the metal ion complexing agents, regulating the crystallization time and pretreating the zeolite precursor gel by adding Ce ions. Thus, glucose as a complexing agent, 48 h of crystallization time and 0.25 of Ce/Si molar ratio were selected which would be further discussed in the following section. Under the assistance of TPA+ ions, the added Ce ions tended to pre-crystallization with the zeolite gel during long-time stir. And then the metal-glucose mixed solution was introduced into the gel system in which metal ions could interact with Si framework by the electrostatic adsorption. After calcination in flowing air and reduction, the carbon from glucose pyrolysis was gasified and Ce-modified alloy-type catalysts were produced. There detected obvious Ni element according to the element mapping results in Fig. 1(b). In addition, according to the XPS etching results in Fig. 1(c), the atomic concentration of metal elements slowly increased with etching time. These phenomena may attribute to the incomplete zeolite crystallization forming an adherent palisade structure as well as an incomplete encapsulation structure that are caused by the short crystallization time and the change of complexing agents in comparison with the previous work [11]. 3.2 Tuning the DRM reactivity of Ni-based ADM catalysts Previously, the impact of complexing agent types, hydrothermal time and Ce/Si molar ratio of support on the DRM reactivity of ADM supported Ni catalysts, to acquire the most suitable catalyst synthesis parameters preparing for the further alloy interface regulation, and the results are summarized in Fig. S1. As shown in Fig. S1(a–c), it was found that catalyst stability was obviously optimized after Ce incorporation in comparison with Ni1Co@A catalyst and achieved the optimal when Ce/Si molar ratio attained 0.25. At this value, CH4 and CO2 conversions of Ni1Co@0.25C-A catalyst could maintain at approximately 70 and 85 % unchanged, and H2/CO molar ratio kept at 0.92. SEM, XRD and FTIR results in Figs. S2 and S3 present that the typical hexagonal sheets of MFI zeolite gradually destroyed with Ce addition but the MFI zeolite skeleton structure still well maintained. Additionally, XRD and Raman results in Fig. S4 demonstrate that 2.5 of Ce/Si molar ratio made the catalyst have good anti-sinter and coke-tolerance abilities due to the formed the strongest metal-support interaction as revealed in H2-TPR profiles (Fig. S3(d)). This can lead to the optimal stability of Ni1Co@0.25C-A catalyst. The results in Fig. S1(d) exhibited the catalyst adopted glucose as the complexing agent and treated at 180 ℃ for 96 h had superior DRM performance and meanwhile had similar CH4/CO2 conversions. The variation of Pt loading can impress the metal dispersion, Ni particle diameter, alloy composition and interface electronic structure, which in turn affects catalyst reactivity. The results in Fig. 2 (a–c) revealed that adding Pt into Ni-Co bimetallic catalytic system can regulate the transformation efficiency of CH4 and CO2 and thus change H2/CO molar ratio of export syngas. In contrast to Ni1Co@0.25C-A catalyst, controlling the content of Pt in 0.25–0.5 wt.%, it was found that both the initial CH4 and CO2 conversions had a slight increase, which demonstrates that the active centers dispersed on the Co-rich Ni-Pt-Co trimetallic catalysts possess higher catalytic activity. Further increasing Pt content to 0.75 wt.%, the initial CH4 conversion and H2/CO molar ratio of Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A catalyst increased to 80 % and 1.13, while its in initial CO2 conversion decreased to 71 % approximately. Giving the limited active center amount and the adsorption competition between CH4 and CO2, this phenomenon can be link to the enhance CH4 adsorption/activation competitiveness of active center over Pt-rich Ni-Pt-Co trimetallic catalysts. For proving the above-mentioned inferences, 24 h of DRM performance evaluation over Ni1Pt@0.25C-A catalyst was carried out. The result showed that Ni1Pt@0.25C-A catalyst had 72 %/60 % of initial CH4/CO2 conversions, 1.28 of initial H2/CO molar ratio, further demonstrating that: (i) Ni-Pt-Co trimetallic catalysts especially the Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A had the higher DRM activity than Ni-Co or Ni-Pt bimetallic catalysts, attributing to the specific trimetallic synergistic effect; (ii) the effect of Pt doping Ni1Co@0.25C-A on the tuning of reactant adsorption/activation rate depends on Pt content, which would be deeply investigated in the following sections. It is noted that trimetallic catalysts exhibited higher stability during 24 h of DRM reaction compared to the bimetallic catalysts, indicating that the trimetallic synergistic effect benefits to the anchor and stabilization of active centers. Additionally, 100 h of long-term stability over Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A catalyst (Fig. 2(d)) unfolded a steady CH4 CO2 conversion at 700 ℃ without obvious activity loss. Both the conversions of CH4 and CO2 decreased by 7 %, and H2/CO molar ratio decreased by 0.1 during stability tests, illustrating the superficial active centers of Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A catalyst is stable for CH4-CO2 reforming to generate syngas. Furthermore, by comparing the performance of Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A catalyst with other noble metal modified or trimetallic catalysts (Table S2), it can be concluded that the designed Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A catalyst is suitable for DRM process. Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@A catalyst was synthesized and its DRM performance was tested under the same conditions with Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A catalyst, to study the impact of Ce addition on the activity of trimetallic active centers. For Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@A catalyst, its initial CH4/CO2 conversions and H2/CO molar ratio were 71 %/58 % and 1.00, and then respectively decreased to 60 %/45 % and 0.90 after 24 h of DRM reaction. The obvious DRM performance gap compared with Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A catalyst indicates that Ce species incorporated into ADM skeleton participates in the construction of the active centers, and plays a significant role in enhancing the cracking capability of the CH and CO bonds. 3.3 Structure-property characterization An in-depth investigation aimed at the geometric structure, electronic properties, and adsorption strength with reactants of Ni-based catalysts was carried out to illustrate the catalytic nature of NixPt(1-x)Co@0.25C-A and Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@A catalysts in DRM. Fig. 3(a) and (b) show the XRD patterns of the calcined and reduced catalysts, respectively. As depicted in Fig. 3(a), the peaks at 7.97°, 8.82°, 23.08° and 23.95° corresponding to MFI zeolite were detected in the calcined Ni0.75Pt0.25Co/A catalyst but absent in all NixPt(1-x)Co@0.25C-A catalysts [11,27]. The peaks at 26.6° can be ascribed to SiO2 phase. These phenomena demonstrated that Ce addition strongly affects the crystallization process and induces the reconstruction of MFI zeolite structure, in line with the results in Figs. S2, S3(a) and S3(b). There was no observation of characteristic peaks corresponding to metal oxides (NiO, Co2O3, CeO2), attributing to their high dispersion and low surface content. Furthermore, the diffraction peaks at 39.8°, 46.2° and 67.5° assigned to (111), (200) and (220) crystal planes of metallic Pt were detected in all calcined catalysts except for in the Ni1Co@0.25C-A catalyst [28,29]. After reduction in 10 vol.% H2/N2 flow for 2 h, new peak appeared at approximately 44.3° that attributes to Ni-Co alloy in the reduced Ni1Co@0.25C-A catalyst [30,31]. Additionally, with the increasing Pt content and decreasing Co content, the diffraction peaks of Ni-Co alloy disappeared, while the characteristic peaks corresponding to Ni-Pt-Co trimetallic alloy at 41.2° and 48.1° strengthened and migrated towards low-angle region. These phenomena indicate that the increased Pt can promote adjacent Ni and Co cations to incorporate into metallic Pt nanoparticles and then produce the preference phase of Ni-Pt-Co alloys instead of forming the segregated Pt metal nanoparticles and Ni-Co alloys. Besides, as comparison to the Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A catalyst, the peaks of trimetallic alloys were found obviously having a low-angle migration in Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@A catalyst, indicating that there exists strong interaction between Ce and alloys beneficial for alloy stabilization. TEM images, element mapping results of all reduced catalysts are shown in Fig. 3(c), (d) and Figs. S5–S8. The TEM images at 50 nm scale presented that Ce addition changed the hexagonal sheets of ADM zeolite (as seen in that of Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A catalyst) into palisade shapes, and then form the structures of metallic nanoparticles highly dispersed on palisade-shaped ADM zeolite during the one-pot hydrothermal process. According to the particle size distribution, it was observed that increasing Pt content could favor the dispersion of metallic nanoparticles and keep its mean particle size approximately 6 nm. The combination of HRTEM images at 2 nm scale and element mapping results are adopted to acquire the information of alloy phase composition variations. For the Ni1Co@0.25C-A catalyst shown in Fig. S5, the closely contacted lattice fringes corresponding to Ni (111), Ni (200), Co (111) and CeO2 (220), and overlapped element distribution of Ni, Co and Ce, illustrate the formation of Ce interacted with Ni-Co alloys, in line with the XRD results [11,32,33]. Furthermore, with the increasing Pt content, this specific structure gradually transformed into Co-rich Ni-Pt-Co trimetallic alloys (in Ni0.25Pt0.75Co@0.25C-A), trimetallic alloys (in Ni0.5Pt0.5Co@0.25C-A), Pt-rich trimetallic alloys (in Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A), and Ni-Pt bimetallic alloys (in Ni1Pt@0.25C-A). Note that the lattice fringes of Co and CeO2 are not easy to be detected like Pt metal, due to the difference in segregation energy as well as the highly dispersed Co and CeO2 species with low surface content. As for the Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A catalyst which was also proved having the structures of Pt-rich trimetallic alloys, while the absence of Ce was found making the Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@A catalyst equip with the smallest mean particle size of 5.03 nm. This may attribute to the maintained high surface area of hexagonal ADM zeolite sheets [19]. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms in Fig. S9(a) and pore diameter distribution in Fig. S9(b) showed that all the catalysts exhibited the combination of Type I and Type IV isotherms which were equipped with the H4-typed hysteresis hoops, relating to the formation of specific micropore-mesopore composite channels in the NixPt(1-x)Co@0.25C-A and Ni0.75Pt0.25Co/A catalysts during the hydrothermal process [11]. Amongst, the pore diameter of NixPt(1-x)Co@0.25C-A catalysts centered at approximately 1.3 nm, 3–8 nm and 9 nm, and that of Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@A catalyst centered at 1.2 nm and 2.7 nm, illustrating that the Ce existed affects catalyst texture and induces the transformation from micropores to mesopores. This is consistent with the phenomena in Table 1 that micropore area decreased and pore volume increased after Ce addition. Additionally, NixPt(1-x)Co@0.25C-A catalysts were found having similar specific surface area and pore volume, indicating that Pt/Co content regulation has no obvious impact on catalyst pore channel structures. Fig. 3(e) shows FTIR spectra of the reduced NixPt(1-x)Co@0.25C-A and Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@A catalysts. As shown in Fig. 3(e), all the catalysts exhibited analogical FTIR vibrational bands. The bands at 3450 and 1640 cm−1 attribute to the surface hydroxyl and water molecules physically absorbed on the catalyst surface [34], respectively. The bands at approximately 1230, 1095, 796, 540 and 460 cm−1 belong to the characteristic stretching vibrations of Si-O and Si-O-Si bonds in MFI zeolite skeleton [35]. It was noted that the variation strength of Si-O and Si-O-Si bonds in NixPt(1-x)Co@0.25C-A catalysts obviously weakened in comparison to the Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@A catalyst, due to the partial destruction and transformation of MFI zeolite skeleton after Ce addition as proposed in TEM and N2 adsorption-desorption results. There was no detection of the characteristic vibration bands corresponding to Ni-phyllosilicates (Ni-P) in the reduced samples. For further recognizing the skeleton Ni in NixPt(1-x)Co@0.25C-A and Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@A catalysts, UV–vis spectra were carried out. The detected UV adsorption bands at approximately 200 nm and 260 nm can attribute to the charge transfer from O2− to Ni2+ in -Ni-O-Si- structures [36], indicating the preservation of Ni2+ strongly interacted with support framework after reduction. H2-TPR results are exhibited in Fig. 3(g) and Table 1. For Ni1Co@0.25C-A catalyst, there detected a bimodal distribution produced due to the overlapped multipeak reduction, determining that it is difficult to deconvolve the H2-TPR curve. Amongst, peak I at 350–550 ℃ attributes to the reduction of Ni2+ or Co2+ species weakly interacted with the Ce-modified ADM zeolite, and peak II at 600–850 ℃ is related to the Ni2+ or Co2+ species strongly interacted with the support skeleton as the form of phyllosilicates or coordinating with Ce4+ [11,26]. In comparison with the Ni1Co@0.25C-A catalyst, the peak I had no obvious changes after Pt introduction. Additionally, a migration was found in peak II with Pt/Co content. This may relate to the variations on Co-phyllosilicate amount or the changed interaction strength between Ni2+ or Co2+ specie and Ce4+ in support skeleton with Pt/Co content. Specially in Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A catalyst, peak II migrated to the highest temperature region at 765 ℃, demonstrating that Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A catalyst has the strongest metal-support interaction beneficial to sinter resistance. Furthermore, it was noted that the absence of Ce in Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@A catalyst made peak I area increase and peak II migrate towards low-temperature compared with Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A catalyst, which illustrates the significant role of Ce in stabilizing metal cations. The new peaks at approximately 180 ℃ corresponding to the reduction of oxygen species adsorbed on surface oxygen vacancy were detected in all reduced NixPt(1-x)Co@0.25C-A catalysts but absent in Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@A catalyst. This demonstrates that Ce addition favors to form oxygen vacancies, which also can be used to explain the lowest reduction degree in Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@A catalyst as shown in Table 1. Note, due to the fact that partial Pt cations have been reduced after calcination, there exists an error between the obtained reduction degree of Pt-modified catalysts with the actual value. Table 1. Physical and chemical properties of the calcined NixPt(1-x)Co@0.25C-A and Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@A catalysts. XPS spectra were adopted to distinguish the electronic structure and coordination environment, the full XPS spectra and fitting results are presented in Fig. S10 and Table S3–S6, respectively. For Ni 2p3/2 XPS spectra in Fig. 4(a) , there detected four peaks in all reduced catalysts after deconvolution which can be assigned to metallic Ni (Ni0) at approximately 853.0 eV, Ni2+ species strongly interacted with zeolite skeleton at 856.5 eV, Ni-P structures maintained after reduction at 859.1 eV and the satellite peak (Sat.) at 862.4 eV, respectively. In contrast to the Ni1Co@0.25C-A, the peaks of Ni species migrated towards higher binding energy with Pt content, due to the enhanced metal-support interaction after Pt addition. Ce absence in Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@A catalyst was observed making the Ni peaks obviously migrate towards lower binding energy, demonstrating the electron transfer from Ni metal to Ce4+ in NixPt(1-x)Co@0.25C-A catalysts that endows the newly formed Ni0 species with electron-defect states as compared to the Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@A catalyst. Furthermore, as shown in Table 2 , Ni1Co@0.25C-A and Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A catalysts had better Ni0/Ni values compared with other catalysts, indicating there existed more active sites on the surface of Ni1Co@0.25C-A and Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A catalysts. This result is in accordance with the H2-TPR results. In addition, Ce presence significantly increased the Ni° content on the catalyst surface, thus benefiting to provide more coordination-unsaturated kink, edge, terrace sites for methane activation [37]. Due to the overlap between C 1 s and Pt 4d spectra, Pt 4f spectra were investigated in this section. Furthermore, taking the fact that Pt 4f doublet also overlaps with Ni 3p spectrum at approximately 66.0 eV, Pt 4f7/2 was not considered. Previous investigation [11] showed that the acid treatment of ATP could lead to a low Al/Mg content on the catalyst surface, which also can be confirmed by the Mg 2p XPS spectra (in Fig. S11). Herein, just the Pt 4f5/2 spectra were considered in this work to ensure the electronic structure of Pt. Fig. 4(b) reveals that Pt addition favors the interaction between surface Pt metallic sites and the support, and meanwhile the significant role of Ce existence as the electron receiver in stabilizing metallic sites is also emphasized. Generally, the fitted peaks appeared at 780.1 eV and 781.7 eV in Co 2p3/2 XPS spectra (in Fig. 4(c)) closely correspond to the Co metal (Co0) and the Co2+ species or Co-P structures that strongly interact with zeolite skeleton [38], respectively. Clearly, Ce addition increased the binding energy of Co peaks in NixPt(1-x)Co@0.25C-A catalysts, attributing to the process that electrons in Co metal transfers into Ce4+. In addition, the variations of Co peaks on peak migration and surface Co0/Co values with Pt addition were found being similar with that of Ni and Pt peaks. The above-mentioned variations with Pt and Ce addition also can be observed in Si 2p spectra. Si peak was found migrating towards the high binding energy region with Pt content but moving into the low binding energy region without Ce existence. Combining with the analyses above mentioned, it can be deduced that the introduction of Ce4+ receives the electrons from metal sites (Ni, Pt and Co) and skeleton silicon that strengthens the anchor of zeolite support on active sites, and benefits to the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ and the formation of oxygen vacancies. Additionally, note that the metal-support interaction of NixPt(1-x)Co@0.25C-A catalysts enhanced with Pt content, but could limit the reduction of Ni2+/Co2+/Pt2+ species if Pt excess. The formation of VO in Ce-modified catalysts was reported closely linked to the produced Ce3+ in CeO2 matrix, thereby Ce 3d XPS spectra were conducted to acquire the VO concentration information on the catalyst surface by calculating the proportion of Ce3+ species [39,40]. The detected u and v peaks in Ce 3d spectra (Fig. 4(e)) were produced due to the spin-orbit splitting of Ce 3d5/2 and Ce 3d3/2, in which the labeled u′′′, u′′, u, v′′′, v′′, and v peaks are corresponded to the Ce4+ species as well as the u′ and v′ peaks can attribute to the Ce3+ species [41]. The Ce3+/Ce values summarized in Table 2 had no obvious changes with Pt addition, indicating that regulating Pt/Co content cannot affect the VO concentration. O 1 s spectra (in Fig. 4(f)) can be divided into four peaks centered at 530.2, 531.2 532.6 and 533.5 eV that are assigned to the lattice oxygen species, the adsorbed oxygen species in VO, and the surface hydroxyl species as well as adsorbed water [11], respectively. Generally, the proportion of the adsorbed oxygen species in VO which is named as VO/O in Table 2 are considered as a standard for evaluating VO concentration. The VO/O value was found having no significant changes with Pt addition, in line with the Ce3+/Ce values in Table 2. It is noted that the low content of VO and lattice oxygen species can attribute to the ex-situ XPS experiments that causes abundant water in air adsorbing on catalyst surface and shielding the signals of VO and lattice oxygen species. For the Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@A catalyst, Ce absence led to the lowest VO/O value of 0.01. It is illustrated that Ce addition is in favor of forming abundant VO on the catalyst surface. O2-TPD profiles in Fig. 5(a) present a bimodal distribution in which the peaks at 50–250 ℃ correspond to the desorption of O2−, O2 2−and O − species absorbed on surface VO, and the peaks above 250 ℃ are caused by the desorbed lattice oxygen species on catalyst surface/bulk [42]. The variations of O2 desorption amounts at 50–250 ℃ shown in Table 3 with Pt addition and Ce introduction were found in accord with the VO concentration in XPS results. CO2 desorption peaks (Fig. 5(b)) of all the reduced catalysts can be deconvoluted into three regions: below 200 ℃, 200–350 ℃, above 350 ℃, attributing to the weak, medium and strong alkaline sites. The catalysts were found mainly exposing medium-strength alkaline sites accompanied by a few weak and strong alkaline sites. It could be acquired from Table 3 that the existence of Ni-Pt-Co trimetallic alloys and Ce addition favored the formation of surface alkaline sites especially the medium-strength that are closely linked to the adsorption and activation of CO2 [43], which is in line with the variations on CO2 conversion with Pt and Ce addition. 3.4 Investigation on catalyst deactivation mechanism Carbon deposition, sintering, metal site oxidation and alloy phase segregation were reported being the main reasons for Ni-based catalyst deactivation. To further reveal the impact of Pt addition and Ce doping on the DRM stability, characterization techniques such as TEM, XPS, TG and Raman were performed on the spent catalysts undergoing 24 h of DRM reaction. TEM results of the spent catalysts are summarized in Fig. 6 and Figs. S12–15. In contrast to the reduced catalysts, the spent catalysts were observed exhibiting similar morphology characteristics and nanoparticle dispersion but being surrounded by many vimineous carbon nanotubes. The spent Ni1Co@0.25C-A, Ni0.25Pt0.75Co@0.25C-A Ni0.5Pt0.5Co@0.25C-A and Ni1Pt@0.25C-A catalysts had smaller particle size compared with the reduced catalysts, due to particle redispersion caused by the surface carbon deposition. While the particle size of Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A catalyst had no obvious change after long-term reaction, illustrating that Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A catalyst has high structure stability and anti-sinter ability. Furthermore, no detection of alloy phase segregation was occurred during DRM process basing on the reciprocal doping of lattice fringes in HRTEM images and overlapped element distribution element mapping results, as well as the existence of electron transfer between metallic species detected in the XPS spectra of spent catalysts as shown in Fig. S16. These demonstrates that catalyst deactivation has no connection with sintering and alloy phase segregation. For the XRD patterns depicted in Fig. S17, excepted for the peaks detected at corresponding to SiC species, there was no observation of any alloy phrase or metal phrases in the spent catalysts in contrast to the reduced catalysts. It demonstrates that metallic nanoparticles and alloys experienced particle redistribution and then highly dispersed on the support, in line with the TEM results of spent catalysts. Fig. 6(d) shows the corresponding TG curves. It was revealed that one-dimensional carbon nanotubes rather than encapsulated carbon are the main coke form in CO2-rich environment. Combining with the TEM results of spent catalysts, the obvious catalyst weight loss detected ranging from 400 ℃ to 700 ℃ attributes to the oxidation of carbon nanotubes. This ensures the catalyst activity loss can be control under 50 % of initial activity [44]. The sample weight loss at 400–700 ℃ are summarized as follows that Ni1Co@0.25C-A (17.96 wt.%) > Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@A (13.68 wt.%) > Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A (13.04 wt.%) > Ni1Pt@0.25C-A (10.76 wt.%) > Ni0.5Pt0.5Co@0.25C-A (8.20 wt.%) > Ni0.25Pt0.75Co@0.25C-A (4.29 wt.%). Considering the tested sample was the mixture of spent catalyst, SiC species and carbon deposition, the mean carbon deposition amounts (gcarbon·gcat −1·h−1) are evaluated using the equation that 5*(sample weight loss at 400 −700 ℃)/reaction time. As shown in Fig. 6(e), compared to Ni1Co@0.25C-A catalyst, Ni1Pt@0.25C-A catalyst and Pt modified catalysts were found presenting lower carbon formation rate, due to the higher carbon adsorption energy barrier on Pt surface that restricts the nucleation and growth of C* species. Note, 0.027 gcarbon·gcat −1·h−1 of carbon formation rate obtained in the Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A catalyst can attribute to its high CH bond rupturing activity and similar surface alkaline site amount and oxygen vacancy concentration with the remaining NixPt(1-x)Co@0.25C-A catalysts. For the Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@A catalyst, the absence of Ce led to a relative high carbon formation rate of 0.029 gcarbon·gcat −1·h−1 due to the low oxygen vacancy concentration on the catalyst surface. Additionally, there was no detection of sample weight increase at 250–400 ℃ corresponding to the oxidation of metal phase [43], which illustrates the high anti-oxidation ability protects the synthesized catalysts from O* active species during DRM process. Raman spectra are given in Fig. 6(f). All the spent catalysts were found having two peaks. The peaks at approximately 1350 cm−1 which are named as D-band are related to the defective carbon including sp3 hybrid carbon and partial broken sp2 hybrid carbon. G-band at 1580 cm−1 are attributed to the stretching vibrations of C=C bonds in sp3 hybrid carbon, indicative of existing graphitic carbon mainly as the form of carbon nanotubes [19,34]. It was reported that coke deposition removal rate is closely linked with the coke nature [45], herein, ID/IG (peak intensity ratio of D-band to G-band) values which indicate the defective degree of carbon deposition were calculated, and the result are shown in Fig. 6(e). Clearly, trimetallic catalysts especially the Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A catalyst presented lower ID/IG values compared to the Ni1Co@0.25C-A and Ni1Pt@0.25C-A catalysts. It demonstrates that the existence of Ni-Pt-Co alloys endows the catalyst with high methane dehydrogenation ability than Ni-Co and Ni-Pt alloys, thus favoring the formation of carbon nanotubes and decreasing the ID/IG values. In addition, the ID/IG value of Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@A catalyst was 1.07 slightly higher than that of Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A catalyst (ID/IG=1.04), illuminating Ce addition benefits to the increase of CH bond breaking capability by strongly interacting with the Ni-Pt-Co alloys. Therefore, the catalyst deactivation can attribute to the growth of carbon nanotubes that causes partial active area loss, instead of active site sinter, metal oxidation or alloy phase segregation. 3.5 Effects of alloy interface regulation and Ce addition on DRM reaction mechanism For insight of the roles of alloy interfacial regulation and Ce addition on the adsorption/activation of CH4/CO2 and production of intermediates during DRM reaction, in-situ DRIFTS measurements were performed. As depicted in Fig. 7(a) , the vibration bands at 3732/3605 cm−1 and 2360 cm−1 can be recognized as the hydroxyl species and CO2 molecules absorbed on the catalyst surface [46], respectively. The characteristic bands detected at 1300, 3015 and 1342 cm−1 are attributed to the vibrations of gaseous CH4, surface absorbed CH4 and the CHx* species formed by methane dehydrogenation [47,48]. The bands appeared at 1730–2080 cm−1 corresponding to the bridge-absorbed CO on metallic sites [49]. Additionally, the IR bands at 1543/1655, 1431 and 1597 cm−1 are assigned to the vibrations of the adsorbed bicentate carbonates, monodentate carbonates and formate species produced due to CO2 adsorption and transformation [11,50]. The vibrations of CO2, CH4 and their derived intermediates were found strengthening with time and then remaining unchanged, demonstrating the adsorption and activation of both CH4 and CO2 gradually reached balanced. Furthermore, the detected stronger variation strength at 1431 and 1730–2080 cm−1 than that at 1543/1655 and 1597 cm−1 indicates that CO2 molecules mainly adsorb on surface VO as the form of monodentate carbonates and then decompose into CO*/O* species, and the remaining CO2 can converse into CO products by the carbonates or formate intermediates. After stopping CO2 injection, the bands at 2360 cm−1 (Fig. 7(b)) were found weakening with time, due to the fact that CO2 can still strongly bond into the catalyst surface in CH4-rich atmosphere and then gradually suppling O* active species or forming formates to restrain carbon accumulation. In comparison with the Ni1Co@0.25C-A catalyst, the vibration strength of bands corresponding to the adsorbed CH4 and CO2 in Fig. 7 (c) and Fig. 7 (d) strengthened, demonstrating that the Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A catalyst possesses higher adsorption/activation of CH and CO bonds due to the existed Ce-modified Ni-Pt-Co alloy interfaces and abundant alkaline sites as well as high VO concentration. Ni1Pt@0.25C-A catalyst shown in Fig. 7(e) presented high CH4 adsorption band vibrations than Ni1Co@0.25C-A catalyst, but it is found that its CO2 adsorption band vibrations obviously weakened and the bands corresponding to the formates were absent. It is indicated that Ni1Pt@0.25C-A catalyst has weak CO2 adsorption capability which restricts the formates-mediated l-H mechanism. This deduction is in accord with the higher OH− vibration strength and the nearly disappeared CO2 adsorption bands after stopping CO2 injection for 18 min as shown in Fig. 7(f). As shown in Fig. 8(a) , compared to the Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@A catalyst, the absence of Ce was found making the bands at 3015 cm−1 slightly weak but causing an obvious decrease in band strength at 2360 cm−1 weak. Additionally, it is observed in Fig. 8(b) that CO2 adsorption bands completely disappeared. Herein, it can be concluded that alloy interface regulation and Ce addition determine the adsorption/activation of CH4 and CO2 molecules during DRM process. The optimal Co/Pt content in Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A catalyst promote the formation of VO, and meanwhile the electron-rich in skeleton Ce is beneficial for alloy phase stabilization by enhancing the metal-support interaction. Furthermore, Pt existence in Ce-modified trimetallic alloy interfaces enhance the CH bond cracking ability. Therefore, Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A catalyst presented the best DRM activity and good long-term stability by a promoted formates-mediated L-H mechanism [11] which is exhibited in Fig. 8(c). 4 Conclusion In this work, NixPt(1-x)Co@0.25C-A (x = 0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1) catalysts were fabricated adopting a one-pot hydrothermal method and applied in DRM process. The activity of the formed Ni-Pt-Co alloy interfaces for CH4/CO2 activation was regulated by adjusting Pt/Co content, among which the existed Pt promoted CH bond dissociation, and meanwhile Co addition favored the adsorption and activation of CO2 as well as the occurrence of formates-mediated L-H mechanism. Furthermore, Ce species in zeolite support were found inducing the formation of VO and beneficial to the stabilization of alloy phases. Due to the superior Ce-interacted Ni-Pt-Co trimetallic alloy interfaces, Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A catalyst presented high CH4 and CO2 initial conversion of 80 % and 71 % and demonstrated good stability during 100 h of DRM reaction. The synergistic multifunction strategy to construct Ce-interacted Ni-Pt-Co trimetallic alloy interfaces with high structure stability and VO concentration from the attitudes of modifying active center and support skeleton in this work, may applicable to develop a novel Ni-based clay catalyst for DRM reaction. coredata.dc:description: Dry reforming of methane (DRM) over Ni-based catalysts is a vital strategy of significant economic and environmental benefits to mitigate the greenhouse effect and facilitate syngas generation, in which catalyst deactivation is the critical bottleneck due to metal sinter and carbon deposition. Herein, a series of NixPt(1-x)Co@0.25C-A (x = 0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1) catalysts were synthesized and employed in DRM. Results demonstrated that regulating Pt/Co content could induce the formation of Ni-Pt-Co trimetallic alloy interfaces and affect the CH/CO bond cracking ability of as-synthesized catalysts. Ce addition in zeolite pre-crystallization process was favorable to increase the oxygen vacancy (VO) concentration to promote CO2 dissociation and coke removal. In addition, Ce species could strongly interact with the trimetallic alloy sites and skeleton silicon by electron transfer, and thus achieving the strong anchoring effect of clay-based zeolite support on active sites and restricting its sinter and phase segregation. Consequently, Ni0.75Pt0.25Co@0.25C-A catalyst, which equips with the superior Ce-interacted Ni-Pt-Co trimetallic alloy interfaces and high VO concentration as well as abundant surface medium-strength alkaline sites, exhibited the highest CH4/CO2 initial conversion of 80 %/71 % and had 7 % of activity loss after 100 h of long-term stability tests.
coredata.dc:title: Ni-Pt-Co clay catalysts for dry reforming of methane: Influence of trimetallic interfaces and Ce addition
